slides.title: Why Structure Data?
slides.content:
# Organization ğŸ—„ï¸

A Data Structure is a way to store and organize data so it can be used efficiently.
- Choosing the right one makes code fast ($O(1)$).
- Choosing the wrong one makes code slow ($O(n)$).

slides.title: Arrays
slides.content:
# The Shelf ğŸ“

A collection of items stored in contiguous memory.
- **Access**: Instant ($O(1)$) if you know index.
- **Search**: Slow ($O(n)$) unless sorted.
- **Resize**: Hard (Fixed size usually).

slides.title: Linked Lists
slides.content:
# The Chain ğŸ”—

Items (Nodes) scattered in memory, each pointing to the next.
- **Resize**: Easy (Just change pointers).
- **Access**: Slow ($O(n)$) - must follow the chain.
- **Insert/Delete**: Fast.

slides.title: Stacks
slides.content:
# Stack of Plates ğŸ½ï¸

LIFO (Last In, First Out).
- **Push**: Add to top.
- **Pop**: Remove from top.
- Used in: Undo button, Backtracking algorithms.

slides.title: Queues
slides.content:
# The Line ğŸš¶ğŸš¶ğŸš¶

FIFO (First In, First Out).
- **Enqueue**: Add to back.
- **Dequeue**: Remove from front.
- Used in: Printer tasks, Web server requests.

slides.title: Order Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which data structure follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle?

slides.title: Hash Tables / Maps
slides.content:
# Key-Value Pairs ğŸ”‘

- Uses a Hash Function to compute index.
- **Lookup**: Super fast ($O(1)$).
- Example: Phone book (Name $\to$ Number).
- The most useful general-purpose structure.

slides.title: Trees
slides.content:
# Hierarchy ğŸŒ³

- **Root**: Top node.
- **Leaves**: Nodes with no children.
- Used in: File systems, DOM (HTML).

slides.title: Binary Search Trees (BST)
slides.content:
# Organized Tree ğŸŒ²

Left child is smaller, Right child is bigger.
- Allows fast searching ($O(\log n)$), like a sorted list but easier to insert into.

slides.title: Heaps
slides.content:
# Priority Queue ğŸ”ï¸

Tree where parent is always bigger (Max Heap) or smaller (Min Heap) than children.
- **Access**: Instant access to Max/Min item.
- Used in: Scheduling, Pathfinding (Dijkstra).

slides.title: Graphs
slides.content:
# Networks ğŸ•¸ï¸

Nodes (Vertices) connected by Edges.
- **Directed**: One-way streets (Twitter follow).
- **Undirected**: Two-way streets (Facebook friend).
- **Weighted**: Distances (Google Maps).

slides.title: Trie (Prefix Tree)
slides.content:
# Autocomplete âŒ¨ï¸

Tree optimized for searching strings.
- Shared prefixes branch off.
- Fast way to find all words starting with "App_".

slides.title: Look up Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which data structure typically offers O(1) average lookup time?

slides.title: Bloom Filters
slides.content:
# Probabilistic ğŸ²

Space-efficient set.
- Can say "Definitely No" or "Maybe Yes".
- Never gives false negatives.
- Used in caching.

slides.title: JSON
slides.content:
# Web Data ğŸŒ

JavaScript Object Notation.
- Tree-like structure of Key-Values.
- Standard for API responses.
- You are reading JSON right now!

slides.title: Databases (SQL)
slides.content:
# Tables ğŸ“‘

Relational Data.
- Rows and Columns.
- Good for structured data with relationships (Users, Orders).

slides.title: NoSQL
slides.content:
# Documents ğŸ“„

Unstructured Data (MongoDB, Firebase).
- Just giant collections of JSON documents.
- Flexible, scales well.

slides.title: Memory Management
slides.content:
# Clean Up ğŸ§¹

- **Stack**: Fast, temporary variables.
- **Heap**: Slow, large objects.
- **Garbage Collection**: Automatic cleanup of unused memory.

slides.title: Data Structures Summary
slides.content:
# Recap ğŸ“

- **Hash Maps** for speed.
- **Trees** for hierarchy.
- **Graphs** for connections.
- Know your tools to write fast code.
